FILE: cm002055v11.0.txt
DYAD: USA - GRENADA
RIVALRY: RIV12
DISPUTE(S): MID3058 

PS-UPDATE2020:

PSNOTES:

PS-LAST-CHANGED: 20220207
PS-LAST-CHECKED: 20220207

Territorial-Maritime-Boundary Issues Variables

MID3058

TERRMID: MID3058 3 -- not territorial 
TERRMID-CER: MID3058 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID3058 from cm narrative, the Grenadan government was overthrown in a coup by the Deputy PM, and a military council took control of the government. The US sent about 8500 troops to Grenada to evacuate students in a medical school there. Various countries and eventually the UN condemned the US invasion, and the US agreed to withdraw in 1983 after providing assistance toward training a police force, with the intention of stabilizing the country. Coded not territorial because no territorial dispute was present. 

TERRLINK: MID3058 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID3058 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES:

MARITMID: MID3058 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID3058 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID3058 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID3058 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES:

CIVWARMID: MID3058 3 -- not civil war
CIVWARMID-CER: MID3058 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID3058 from cm narrative, a coup sparked the US decision to invade Greanda and evacuate American medical students from the country. This is coded not civil war because the violence was from a coup, not a militarized rebel group, and no civil war broke out. 

CIVWARLINK: MID3058 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID3058 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES:

COUPMID: MID3058 1 -- coup MID
COUPMID-CER: MID3058 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: MID3058 from MID-B data, this is a multilateral MID involving many Caribbean nations and the US against Cuba and Grenada. From cm narrative, the US landed several thousand troops in Grenada when a coup by the deputy Prime Minister deposed the Prime Minister. A military council took power. Coded coup mid because a coup in Grenada led to the US launching troops there to evacuate Americans. From Facts on File (vol. XLIII pg. 787), several Caribbean nations condemned the coup in Grenada and refused to have relations with the new government, while Cuba supported the new government and condemned the US invasion.

COUPLINK: MID3058 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID3058 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: MID3058 This is a multilateral coup MID, coded not coup link because the coup is within this dyad (Grenada). No other coups in this MID. 

RIVNOTES: 

NARRATIVE-CM:
Prime Minister Maurice Bishop of Grenada was overthrown during a rebellion led by Deputy Prime Minister Bernard Coard on October 13-19, 1983, resulting in the deaths of 16 individuals. The 16-member Revolutionary Military Council (RMC) headed by General Hudson Austin took control of the government on October 19, 1983. Some 8,500 United States troops invaded Granada as part of an Organization of East Caribbean States (OECS) military force beginning on October 25, 1983. Some 1,000 US citizens, mainly students of a medical school on the island, were evacuated by the US troops. Nicaragua condemned the US intervention in Grenada, and referred the matter to the United Nations (UN) Security Council on October 25, 1983. President Fidel Castro of Cuba condemned the US intervention in Grenada on October 26, 1983. The Soviet Union condemned the US intervention in Grenada, and demanded an immediate withdrawal of US troops from Grenada on October 26, 1983. Belize appealed for a troop withdrawal from Grenada on October 27, 1983. Shridath Ramphal, the secretary-general of the Commonwealth of Nations (CON), appealed for a troop withdrawal on October 27, 1983. Afghanistan condemned the US intervention in Grenada, and demanded a troop withdrawal from Grenada on October 27, 1983. The US vetoed a UN Security Council resolution on October 28, 1983, which would have called for the withdrawal of foreign troops from Grenada. The OECS established the Caribbean Peacekeeping Force (CPF), which consisted of some 500 troops and police from Dominica, Antigua, Jamaica (450 soldiers), St. Lucia, St. Vincent (12 police), and Barbados (50 police) and 300 non-combat US military personnel commanded by Colonel Delroy Ormsby of Jamaica. The CPF was deployed in Grenada on October 28, 1983. Some 150 individuals were killed during the military intervention, including 85 Grenadan soldiers, 19 US soldiers, and 24 Cuban soldiers. The Coordinating Bureau of the Non-Aligned Movement (NAM) condemned the US intervention in Granada, and appealed for the withdrawal of troops from Grenada on October 28, 1983. The UN General Assembly condemned the US intervention in Grenada and appealed for a troop withdrawal on November 2, 1983. The US government agreed on November 23, 1983 to provide police training assistance to the Grenadan government (a 550-member police force was established with the assistance of the Britain and the US). US combat troops were withdrawn from Grenada on December 15, 1983. US support personnel were withdrawn from Grenada on June 11, 1985, and the CPF completed its withdrawal from Grenada on September 20, 1985.

SOURCES-CM: 
Brecher and Wilkenfeld, 1997, 527-529; Clodfelter, 1992, 1179-1180; Tillema, 1991, 20-21.

NARRATIVE-CR:

SOURCES-CR:

Facts on File, 1983. Vol. 43. New York, NY: Facts on File, inc.
